intro: Serpocaulon loriciforme, commonly known as the lace fern, is a unique vascular plant belonging to the family Hymenophyllaceae. It is a small, delicate fern that typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as on rocks or tree trunks in tropical and subtropical regions. Its fronds are finely divided and often covered in a fine, lace-like pattern, giving it its common name. The plant has a short, creeping rhizome and produces small, spore-bearing leaves called sporophylls. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is often found in humid, high-altitude areas and is considered a rare and specialized species.
